qas.question: What was the medieval flute made from?
What was an early version of the fiddle called?
What was an early version of the trombone called?
Medieval instrument in Europe were commonly used how?
Loud, shrill, and outdoor instruments were referred to as 'haut', while quieter, more intimate instruments were referred to as what?

context: Many of the instruments used to perform medieval music still exist, but in different forms. Medieval instruments included the <a0_0>wood<a0_0/> flute (which in the 21st century is made of metal), the recorder and plucked string instruments like the lute. As well, early versions of the organ, fiddle (or <a1_0>vielle<a1_0/>), and trombone (called the <a2_0>sackbut<a2_0/>) existed. Medieval instruments in Europe had most commonly been used <a3_0>singly<a3_0/>, often self accompanied with a drone note, or occasionally in parts. From at least as early as the 13th century through the 15th century there was a division of instruments into haut (loud, shrill, outdoor instruments) and <a4_0>bas<a4_0/> (quieter, more intimate instruments).
